Sunt enim quaedam
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
. After the Master treated the eternal notions intrinsic to persons, now he begins to treat the temporal and extrinsic relations. And this is divided in two because in the first place he treats about those things which are said extrinsically about any person from time, in the second place about those things which belong to the persons commmonly and appropriately. The second begins at the beginning of distinction 31 at,
praeterea considerare oportet
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
.

The first is divided into three because in the first place he asserts the truth about temporal relations, in the second place he shows how it is possible to for possibility to belong to God, in the third place from these things he solves a difficult. The second begins at
quomodo ergo obtinebimus
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
. The third begins at
hic potest solvi quaestio
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
.

The second principal part
which is distinction 31 is divided into three because in the first place he posits something about divine equality with responses to questions, in the second place he shows similar questions are able to arise likeness and equal solutions are able to be given, in the third place from these things according to the opinions and traditions of two saints. The second begins at
hoc idem dicimus
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
. The third begins at,
non est praetermittendum
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
, etc.

That God does not depend on something contingent, producible, or temporally produced, therefore he does not really relate to any such thing. The antecedent is known, and the consequence is clear because, what relates to another things, depends on that thing.

In the second place, if this is so, then either this would be a relation distinct from itself and from any absolute thing or it would be related to itself. Not the first because when a relation is related to God, it follows that there is a relation of the relation, and thus there would be a process into infinity in relations, which is false. Again, it follows that which mediates the relation between God and the producible would be in God. The consequent is false because God is not the subject of any accident. And the consequence is clear because non-being is not able to be the subject of an accident. Nor the second because by the same reason any created thing would be related to what is different than itself, which is false because every related thing is distinct from the absolute thing.

In the third place, either God is related to this by a temporal relation or an eternal relation. Not the first because then God would change. This is clear through the
Commentator V Physics, comment 19
Averroes, Physica V, commento 10, xxx
, where he wishes that when something genuinely new comes into being related through the change of another each is changed through an accident or by the relative change. And the second is not able to be said because no creature was eternally, but a real relation is not able to be between two extremes unless they are really positive, therefore.

In opposition, it is argued that God knew from eternity that would produce a creature, therefore the question is true. The consequence holds because the one knowing and the knowable or thing known relate to one another. And the about the antecedent there is no doubt because God does not begin to know anything in time.

First conclusion: though God is related to created things from time or temporally, nevertheless anything to which God relates temporally was already related from eternity or eternally. The first part is clear because God is the creator from time and really the lord of creation, therefore. The antecedent is clear through the
Master, in distinction 30
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 30, xxx
. And the consequence is clear because a lord is related to his servant and the lord is not a lord before his servant exists. The second part is proved because God was eternally foreknowing and productive of what is producible, therefore he was eternally related creatable and knowable being. The consequence is clear the creative and creatable, the knowing and the knowable are correlative. But that is a real relation and not a relation of reason only because having removed every operation of any created thing, it remains that the case that God is creating and the lord of creation and he is related to whatever is producible.

The first corollary: just it is not repugnant that real being is related to something that lacks actual being, so it is not repugnant that non-being is related to the highest necessity. The first part is clear because memory is of things absent and of things past, therefore being is related to non-being. The consequence holds because memory is called memory, as is clear through
Augustinum, X De Trinitate, chapter 10
Augustinus, De Trinitate X, c. 10
. The antecedent is clear from the
Philosopher in De memoria et reminiscentia
Aristoteles, De memoria xxx
. This part is confirmed because the image of a rose existing on a wall or in the memorative power is equally an image of a rose when it is present while it is nonetheless not present, therefore being is related to non-being. The consequence is clear because
the image inasmuch as it is an image is something related. The second part is proved because being is related to non-being, therefore. The consequence holds because relatives are called convertences, and the antecedent is clear from the conclusion and from the position of its first part

Second corollary: though it is impossible that created existing entities do not have dependence, nevertheless not everything having dependence on something is a real entity in existence. The first part is clear because it implies that something is created and does not depend on God because it follows that it exists and does not exist. The second part is proved by taking dependence for any disposition of one thing toward another because non-being has a relative dependence on being, as is clear through what has been said.

Third corollary: though father, as father, and the lord as lord are not able to be related unless to some essence, as they indicate an actual relation and not habitual one, nevertheless some things are relative, to which it is repugnant to be related to real being or to some existing substance. The first part is the determination of
Augustine, VII De Trinitate.
Augustinus, De Trinitate VII, xxx
. In the first place because a father does not exist unless it has a son, and lord does not exist unless it has a servant. The second part is clear because the factive or productive does not relate properly to something real existing being, but to some that is not and is able to be or what is producible. Note here that Gregorius holds that the divine thing is an absolute relative in some mode

Second conclusion: though any discoverable relation between created beings is somehow really distinct from everything thing, nevertheless no such relation apart from the absolute thing is able to be distinctly understood. The first part is proved because a real relation and an absolute thing or a realted thing and an absolute thing, as thus are really found in diverse categories, since they differ not only number and species, but also in genus, therefore. ergo. The antecedent is proved because relation is a category distinct from another from itself. The second part is proved because, if the relation of father and son were ale to be conceived without any thing distinctly absolute, it follows that someone would be able to know for themselves that something is father and not know that he has a son. Again, it would be possible to know that Socrates is similar to not be aware of whether it is similar to something, indeed one would not even know Socrates, since Socrates is an absolute thing. But these things should not be conceded, therefore.
First corollary: that any real relation of creatures is from each term really distinct. This is clear because the foundation or term of a relation is an absolute thing, as is this case.

The second corollary: not every thing related to something by its own relation is really a distinct thing. This is clear because then it would follow that in relations of relations there would be a procession into infinity, as it has been argued above. The consequence is clear because every relation has some disposition to something else, then it is asked whether such relation is related to itself or something else. If the first, the intention is had, If the second, it would be asked about that through what would it be related, just as before, and it follows, having inferred the consequent that there will be a process without end.

Third corollary: by the same real relation one is able to be related to many things because otherwise it would follow that there would be as many paternities in one father as he has sons. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear.

Third conclusion: that the relation of an uncreated being to created being is not prior to the relation of created being to uncreated being. This is proved because from the beginning the creature is equally related to God and God to the creature. I prove this because from eternity the producible creature was related to God, as is clear from the first conclusion.

First corollary: that not anything related to another is ordered to this finally. This is clear because is really related to creature, and nevertheless God is not ordered to it finally, but rather the conversely the creature is ordered to him.

Second corollary: it is the case that something is related to something else by a new relation and having been newly related nothing is conferred to it or there is no change in what has been related. This is clear
because the creator is related in time to the existing creature, but the creator is not intrinsically susceptible to something new or to an accident, therefore

Third corollary: it is not the case that every relation is an accident and it is in any of the related things formally. This is clear because, if any relation were an accident inhering formally in any of the related things, it follows that in God there would be an accident, which is false. And the consequence is clear since he is really related to created things, as is clear from what has been said.

From what has been said, it is clear that, though that by which God is disposed relatively to creatures does not depend on a sole act of the intellect, namely effectively, nevertheless it is should not be put in God subiectively or inhesively. The first part is clear because, even when there is no existing created intellect, God would still be disposed relatively toward a piece of wood. The second part is clear because whatever is in God is God. From all these things the affirmative part of the question follows.

Against the first conclusion: God is outside the order of creatures and is not ordered to them, therefore neither is he really related to them. The consequence is clear since thing that are really ordered to one another, these seem to be of the same order.

In the second place, it would follows that God would not be the most simple thing. I prove this because, if he were really related, it follows that there some reality in him which necessarily coacts for his being another term.

In the third place, against this is the Master in this distinction, saying
the name, by which the creature is said to the creator, is relative and it notes the relation which is in the creature. But the name, by which the creator is said relative to the creature, indeed there is something relative, but it does not note a relation, which is in the creator
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
.

In the fourth place against the first corollary, everything that is related is, but nothing that is non-being is, therefore. The major is clear because haec ipsa quot sunt, as is clear in the Categories, but what is not, is not this itself, which is neither of itself nor of another.

In the fifth place, everything that is different is something and being, but every term of a real relation is different from the related, therefore any such thing is a being. The minor is clear because the related is of another.
In the sixth place against the second corollary, it would follow some being would depend on non-being. I prove this because because every relation is a certain dependence on something else.

Against the second conclusion, if the relation in creatures were a distinct thing from the associated, it follows that God would be able to make a creature without dependence. The consequent is false. Proof of the consequence because God is able to remove the subject from any accident really distinct from it, since he posit that an accident is to separate from a a subject from which it is really distinguished.

In the second place, it is asked by what such dependence is caused effectively whether from a foundation or not. If yes, since God is able to suspend all action of a creature, it follows that the foundation is able to be without such dependence, which is repugnant to what has been said. If it is not caused by a creature but by God, the same consequent follows because God by causing the prior effect is not necessitated to produce the later effect from which the prior is really distinct.

In the third place, the creature and its dependence are produced by the same production, therefore. The consequence holds because the same production is not able to terminate in diverse really distinct things. The antecedent is proved because, if they are produced by diverse productions, it follows that the first would be able to be without the second, and thus the creature would be without the dependence.

In the fourth place, depends on God, apart from everything by which it is not, therefore. The consequence holds. The antecedent is proved because having posited one creature alone and removed it from everything by which it is not this, such a thing is still an effect of God.
In the second place, the antecedent is proved because, if a creature were to depend through another on itself, it follows that it would not depend absolutely, but only secundum quid. The consequence is clear because what depends through another only depends secundum quid. In the third place, the same antecedent is proved because, if a stone were to depend on itself with a distinct dependence,
it would follow that the dependence of a stone, which depends itself, would more greatly depend on God than the stone does. The consequent is false because each depends causally. The consequence is proved because what depends in itself depends first and principally, but what depends in another does not depend on the first, but from the consequent.

In the fifth place, against the second part of the same conclusion, the effect is able to be understood without a cause, therefore the relation without any absolute thing. The consequence holds because understanding of one disparate thing does not depend more on another distinct thing than the understanding of the effect on the understanding of its cause. The antecedent is clear because someone is able to know that something is the father and not know whether it has a son, and conversely that something is able to know that Socrates is a son and to not know whether he has a father.

Against the third conclusion there are the three arguments made in opposition, nevertheless it is argued different against it, just a foundation is disposed to the foundation, so a relation to a relation, but God is prior to the creature, therefore the relation of God to the creature is prior to the relation of the creature to God. Again, the relation of God to the creature is only a relation of reason, therefore it is posterior to the relation of the creature to God. The consequence is clear because every real relation precedes a relation of reason.
To the first, the consequence is denied because similarly it would be proved that the creature is not related to God himself, since it is not of the same order with God.

To the second, the consequence is denied and likewise its proof.
In the second, I say that not every relation go out to its own being because its term is existing in the nature of things.

To the words of the Master, it is said that he intends that when God is related to the creature for the first time, no newness or change is in him, but only in the creature on account of which change the creature is both newly related to God and God is newly related to the creature.

To the fourth, the major is denied, and to the proof it is said that these terms are meant in a different way when taken for those things which are not real entities and do not exist, and thus it is conceded that relatives are said to be of others generally and commonly, when taking the term of others as it is said bout about existing things and about non-existing things.
The same thing is clear with respect to the fifth.

To the sixth, the consequence is denied, and to the proof it is said that not every relations properly is dependence because then a father would depend on the son, and the son on the father, indeed any person would depend on another, since everything is related to something else, which should not be said. Again, a lord is not dependent on his servant, nor cause on what is caused, though no one is able to be a lord unless there is a servant, and there is no cause unless there is something caused.

To the first against the second conclusion, the consequence is denied because a relation is nothing except the disposition of a foundation to a term. To the proof, it is said that, though God would be able to separate an accident of relation from its subject, nevertheless it does not follows that he is able to make an independent creature, which implies a contradiction.

To the second, it is said that this dependence is produced by God as an accident because for the production there is necessarily posited a relation of dependence. And to the proof, because then God would be necessitated, etc., it is said that God is not absolutely necessitated to produce something outside himself, but rather secundum quid and from the supposition of another produced thing, and this is called conditioned necessity or necessity from the supposited.
To the third, the consequence is denied because, though they are produced by the same action, nevertheless the creature is produced per se, but dependence is per accidens.

To the fourth, it is said that for something to depend on another is able to be in two ways, namely formally and fundamentally. In the first mode, it is said that a creature does depend formally on itself, when everything else is restricted by God. But in the second mode, the creature depends on itself in another kind of seclusion. But here we speak of relative formal dependence, and therefore the antecedent is denied.
To the first proof it is said that the case is impossible. In the second place it is said that, if it were admitted, then the creature would depend fundamentally and not formally.
To the second proof, the consequence is denied because this thing depends on itself absolutely fundamentally.
To the third proof, similarly the consequence is denied because, though dependence itself depends formally on God, nevertheless a stone depends fundamentally on itself.

To the fifth principle argument, it is said that, if the antecedent is understood about distinct and perfect intellection, then this is denied. If about confused, then it is conceded, but in this case the argument does not prove anything against the conclusion.

In the second place, it is responded, having conceded the antecedent, by denying the consequence because, whoever distinctly knows one of the relations, knows the others because the being of a relation and the related is being to another, but the being of a stone is not being to another, but to itself, though the being of the effect, in so far as it is an effect, is to another, and thus it is not able to be understood without intellection, etc.

To the first in the opposition, the consequence is denied because, though God does not posit a being to be created that is not something creatable, nevertheless when properly speaking about dependence, God depends on nothing.

To the second, it is said according to
Gregory
Gregorius, XXX
that a relation of God is God, but
Alphonsus
Alphonsus Vargas, XXX
says otherwise.

To the third, it is said, the statement that God is related by an eternal relation, is able to be understood in two ways. In the first mode thus, that the thing, which is a relation, is eternal and is God, such that God is related to everything by an eternal relation because he is related by himself. In the second mode, by an eternal relation, that is, eternally related and temporal, that is, temporally related in time or after was not related in this way. Thus it is said that God is related eternally to somethings which were not in virtue of the fact that he pre-knows this and is related to this temporally inasmuch as he is the creator and lord of these things because, though he was, nevertheless he was not lord. To the proof, because if temporally, then it follows that there is a change in God. The consequence is denied when understanding change properly. And to the Commentator it is said that something changes is able to be understood in two ways. In the first mode properly and strictly., and in this way that is changed relative what is moved according to that thing according which it is related, just as if Socrates were made more similar to Plato in whiteness through the intention of whiteness in Socrates, then Socrates would be properly changed. In another mode improperly and loosely, and thus now everything that is related to what before was not related is able to be said to be changed relatively. And it is in this way that the Commentator speaks of the example in the column, which only through the change of Socrates is able now to be to the right of Socrates dextera which before was to the left. Note that Gregory holds that every entity is aboslute and relative and that no relation is a distinct thing from every absolute thing, contrary to the opinion of Alphonsus. See
Gregory around distinction 28 ad following
Gregorius Ariminiensis, Sent. I, d. 28
.

Sunt enim quaedam
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 30, xxx
. First conclusion of distintion 30: that some names are said of God from time and suit him temporally without any mutation on his part and are said relatively according to an accident which does not occur (accidat) in God, but in creatures, for example creator, lord, refuge, etc.

Second conclusion: thought God did not begin from time to be lord of time, nevertheless God began to be lord of time. The first is clear because time did not begin from time because the world from indicates an order and presupposes time, and thus time would have been before it began to be. The second part is proved because there was not always time.

Third conclusion: somethings are said about God temporally and relatively about creatures without change in the divinity, but not without change in the creature, and thus the accident is in the creature not in the creator.

Fourth conclusion: that the name by which a creature is said relatively is relative to the creator,
and indicates a relation which is in the creature.
Fifth conclusion: the name by which the creator is said relatively is related to the creature, but it does not indicate a relation which is in the creator.

Sixth conclusion: that when we say that the Holy Spirit has been given or donated it is said relatively to the one giving and to the one to whom it is given, nevertheless we do not say that the Holy Spirit is related to itself, even thought it gives itself.

Praeterea considerare
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 31, xx
etc. The first conclusion of the distinction 31: that nothing is called similar or equal to itself, but the three divine persons are said to be equal to one another and relatively similar because equality or likeness is only a relative name but not a relation.

Second conclusion: the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are called equal and similar, not according to relative properties, but according to the unity of the essence, nevertheless the Son is not equal to the Father from the fact that the he is the Son, but according that which is said about itself, that is the substance and virtue and nature, for the equality is the identity of virtue.

Third conclusion: that according to some by the name equality or likeness nothing is posted, but rather is removed, such that Father therefore is said to be equal to the Son because he is not greater or less than the Father, and this is on account of the unity of essence. Similarly, he is said to be simple because he is not diverse nor alien nor dissimilar in some respect, and this is on account of the simplicity of the essence. And thus equality in the divine does not posit some thing, but is said only on account of reason or through removal.

Fourth conclusion: that according to Hilary, the equality of the Father is appropriate for one who is from no one, but he calls the Son the image, to which he attributes the species or beauty on account of the perfect representation of the Father. But he calls the Holy Spirit a gift by virtue of the fact that it is a gift of the Father and the Son, to which he attributes use because all gifts are given to us by him for our benefit.
Fifth conclusion: that eternity and species or beauty and use or delight do not distinguish properties of persons, but show hypostases, and they are appropriately said of them.

Sixth conclusion: that the image, which is the Son, is coequal with the Father, but not to the Son because that the Son is equal to the Father is something that the Son has from the Father, but the Father does not have it from the Son because he is equal to it.

Seventh conclusion: that according to Augustinum unity is appropriate to the Father because, just as unity does not have a principle from which it is, but is the principle of other things, so the Father is without a principle and is the principle of the other persons, but equality is appropriate to the Son because in him the equality in the divinity is found first, but the concordance of each is appropriate to the Holy Spirit because it proceeds from the Father and the Son as love and delight.
The eighth conclusion: that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are rightly said to be one and one God, but they are not able to be called of one.

Ninth conclusion: that when the truth says
I and the Father are one Ioannes 10:30 , this is true in that he says one which excludes the error of Arius who does not wish three person to be of one and the same substance; and in that he says we are he excludes the heresy of Sabellius who posited the name Trinity alone without the subsistence of persons.
